_prev_prog_3.Description: Chemours Washington Works has implemented a detailed PSM Program for its EPA regulated chemicals.  The program covers all elements of the OSHA PSM regulation.  Process Safety Management is also covered in various Corporate and Site Safety Manuals and Engineering Standards. Fluoropolymer - TFE Manufacturing process is comprised of four units.  All units follow the guidance outlined in the Washington Works Safety and Health Procedures for prevention of accidental releases.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Introduction



On July 1, 2015, DuPont completed the separation of its Performance Chemicals segment through the planned spin-off of The Chemours Company ("Chemours").  At the Washington Works facility in West Virginia where both entities reside, Chemours is now the property owner and DuPont is a tenant.



The Chemours Company is a member of the American Chemistry Council and receives external certification of its Responsible Care Management System (RCMS) consistent with those requirements. The Chemours Washington Works site adheres to Corporate Environmental, Health & Safety policies which are a part of that program.  For safety and environmental incidents, these policies can be summarized as follows:

  -We believe all safety and environmental incidents are preventable.

  -Our goal for incidents is zero.

  -We are prepared for emergencies and we will provide leadership for our local communities to 

    help in their emergency preparedness.



Corporate Environmental, Health and Safety (EHS) & RCMS policies are embodied in numerous site procedures along with guidelines and recommended practices in Chemours Engineering Standards. Corporate EHS policies and Washington Works EHS procedures are available for review by all employees.



At Washington Works, EHS policies and procedures are also documented in the Washington Works EHS Manual.  Various procedures throughout the manual deal specifically with Process Safety Management elements to prevent incidents from occurring.  It is the responsibility of every employee and contractor working on our behalf to comply with these procedures.  It is management's responsibility to educate and train employees so they may understand and comply with the procedures. 



Facility Description

The Chemours Washington Works main plant site consists of approximately 450 acres located approximately five miles west of Parkersburg, WV.  Manufacturing operations are located on approximately 170 of the 450 acres.  Polymer resins and pr

oducts in primary forms are manufactured at the site.  In addition to manufacturing operations and associated support facilities, the site also has an area dedicated to wildlife habitat and an island that the site leases to the state for use by the public.

  

Chemours uses the following EPA regulated RMP chemicals at levels above their process threshold quantities:

     Toxics     - anhydrous hydrochloric acid                    

     Flammables - tetrafluoroethylene



General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps



The Washington Works site manufacturing areas follow the requirements set out in Chemours Corporate EHS Standard S21A, Process Safety Management.  This standard includes and embraces the requirements of 29 CFR 1910.119 and 40 CFR Part 68.  The standard involves the following activities as listed below: 



Safety in Design

- A documented process technology system covers hazards of materials, equipment design basis, and process design basis.

- Extensive active and passive preventative and mitigating systems are strategically located.

- Applicable codes and standards are met or exceeded.

- Materials of construction are chosen to provide mechanical integrity.

- Quality Assurance ensures fabrication in accordance with design specifications and proper assembly.



Safety in Maintenance

- Maintenance personnel are trained and experienced.

- Contractors are trained and qualified.

- A work permit system controls hazards.



Safety in Operations

- Operators are trained and job qualified.

- Technical resources are available and utilized as required.

- Operators follow approved procedures.



Safety through Reviews, Inspections, Process Hazards Analysis, Investigation and Auditing

- Routine safety inspections are conducted.

- Corporate and independent audits and reviews are conducted.

- Process Hazards Analyses are conducted.

- Safety critical equipment is set up on a periodic inspection frequency to ensur

e ongoing mechanical integrity.

- Pre-startup safety reviews are conducted prior to starting up any new or modified equipment.

- Quality assurance of critical equipment ensures fabrication in accordance with design specifications.

- All incidents are investigated and actions taken to prevent recurrence. 



These individual activities encompass the parts of our RMP prevention program and we have established specific controls to ensure that we are meeting these standards to prevent accidental releases.



Five-year Accident History

There have been no RMP recordable accidents at the Washington Works facility during the past five years, under DuPont or Chemours. 



Emergency Response Program

The site emergency response program is documented in the Washington Works Emergency Response Manual is available for review by all employees and site tenants.

The Emergency Response program in place at Washington Works is such that plant personnel are trained and equipped to respond to accidental chemical releases.  The program can be summarized as follows:



Training and preparation

  -Plant personnel and emergency responders receive emergency response training.

  -Emergency response plans are periodically reviewed and updated.

  -The plant conducts periodic emergency drills, including critiques.

  -A plant representative actively participates on the Washington County, Ohio and Wood County, West Virginia Local Emergency Planning Committees (LEPCs).



-If a release with the potential for off-site impact occurs:

  -The plant emergency alarm is sounded.

  -The plant Emergency Operations Center (EOC) is activated.

  -Plant emergency personnel respond.

  -Community responders are notified and asked to respond as appropriate.

  -The local Industrial Alert System is activated, if warranted.



Programs detailing emergency responder training and emergency equipment maintenance can be found in the Washington Works S&OH manual, ER manual, and computer-based training progra

ms (TLM).  All of these activities are monitored to ensure they remain current.  



Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Making our processes safer is an on-going program at Washington Works.  Employee suggestions, capital improvements, audit programs, and various other activities help to ensure that we provide safe, reliable processes. Other programs aimed at improving process safety and our emergency response planning include:

  -Recommendations developed during cyclic process hazards analyses that reduce the risks associated with our processes.

  -Providing additional process safety training to technical personnel in topics such as chemical reactivity, layer of protection analysis, and safety instrumented systems risk analysis.

  -Expanding periodic process safety metrics reporting to management.
